content.definition:
adj. Expressing love or the state of being in love.
The couple exchanged amorous glances as they sat across from each other at the dinner table.

v. To present or speak of as unimportant or of little value.
“Why do you always try to make your efforts seem more important by belittling mine?” she complained.

v. To blame or find fault with.
The judge censured the lawyer for failing to file the papers on time.
n. A severe criticism or harsh judgment.
A hundred years ago, people who divorced experienced much greater censure than they do today.

v. To consider; to believe.
Hearing about the train derailment, the mayor deemed it prudent to call up emergency crews from neighboring counties.

v. To make known something secret; to reveal.
Blackbeard divulged the location of the buried treasure to no one.

adj. Exceeding normal bounds; greater or more than seems reasonable.
Two hundred dollars seems an exorbitant price for a man’s shirt.

v. To argue earnestly in an attempt to dissuade or show strong disapproval.
My friends expostulated with me on the wisdom of waiting until the storm had passed before I walked to the park.

adj. Having great or significant consequences.
The article examines President Truman’s fateful decision to drop the atomic bomb on Hiroshima.

n. An ungrateful person.
I felt like an ingrate for forgetting to thank my mother for making the food for my party.

n. 1. An order or command.
When the hurricane warning was announced, my family wisely heeded the injunction to evacuate the island.
2. A court order prohibiting someone from doing something.
The injunction stated that the company could not hire permanent replacement workers during the strike.

adj. Close to death; in a dying state.
It is incontrovertible that the company was moribund when it was taken over last year.

n. 1. A theme or idea in a work of art or literature that is developed or repeated.
Throughout the novel, the author explores the motif of separation.
2. A figure or design repeated in the decoration of something, such as a building or textile.
The wallpaper for the nursery had a rabbit motif.

v. To support by giving financial aid.
Crowdfunding has subsidized countless arts projects, allowing millions of people to enjoy music, dance, and theater in their hometowns.
n. subsidy – A grant of money, often provided by a government to a group or individual.
Thanks to this subsidy, our dance company was able to perform throughout the state.

adj. Extravagantly splendid or costly; luxurious.
After the wedding we enjoyed a sumptuous meal in the hotel dining room.

adj. Characterized by a ready flow of words; talkative.
The voluble host scarcely gave his guests a chance to speak.

pages.name: Understanding Meanings
pages.subheading: Read the following sentences. If the word in bold is used correctly, write C. If the word is used incorrectly, write a new sentence using the word correctly.

content.question: To expostulate is to become confused or perplexed.
content.answer: Incorrect. To expostulate is to argue earnestly in an attempt to dissuade or show strong disapproval.

content.question: A motif is a reason for doing something.
content.answer: Incorrect. A motif is a theme or idea that is developed or repeated in a work of art or literature.

content.question: To belittle something is to claim it is less important than it seems.
To subsidize something is to pay some or all of the cost of it.
A sumptuous hotel resort is one on which no expense has been spared.
To feel amorous is to have thoughts of love.
An ingrate is a person who is not famous.
content.answer: Incorrect. An ingrate is an ungrateful person.

content.question: To divulge something is to draw its attention elsewhere.
content.answer: Incorrect. To divulge something is to make known something secret or to reveal.

content.question: A moribund organization is one that is not open to outsiders.
content.answer: Incorrect. A moribund organization is one that is close to death or in a dying state.

content.question: To censure someone is to deny that person the right to speak.
content.answer: Incorrect. To censure someone is to blame or find fault with them.

content.question: A voluble person is one who is large in size.
content.answer: Incorrect. A voluble person is one who is talkative and speaks with a ready flow of words.

content.question: To deem something impossible is to think that it is so.
A fateful event is one that is momentous.
An injunction is the compacting of trash at a landfill.
content.answer: Incorrect. An injunction is a legal order or command that requires someone to do or refrain from doing something.

content.question: An exorbitant demand is one that is greater than seems reasonable.

content.name: Artists and Soul Mates
passage: When Anita Pollitzer received a batch of charcoal drawings done by an artist friend in South Carolina, an accompanying note told her not to show them to anyone. The work was of value to the artist, but she felt the drawings had little objective merit, and she could not bear the thought of their being belittled by strangers. Pollitzer disagreed with her friend's assessment, so, disregarding the injunction to keep the drawings to herself, she showed them to Alfred Stieglitz, the owner of “291,” a Manhattan art gallery. The usually voluble Stieglitz was silent as he studied the drawings intently. Their abstract shapes, suggestive of forms in nature, were unlike anything he had seen before. Finally he looked up. “What woman did these?” he asked, for he knew instinctively that they had not been drawn by a man. Pollitzer told him they were the work of her friend Georgia O’Keeffe. “I think I will give this woman a show,” Stieglitz replied.

At the time of this fateful conversation in 1916, O’Keeffe was an unknown art teacher in her late twenties, while the fifty-two-year-old Stieglitz had an international reputation as a photographer and art dealer. It was almost entirely due to his efforts that photography had become recognized as one of the fine arts. Camera Work, his sumptuously printed magazine, first appeared in 1903, and his gallery at 291 Fifth Avenue, which opened two years later, sold photographic prints as works of art. An admirer of the painters Picasso and Matisse long before their work was fashionable, Stieglitz introduced these giants of modern art to the American public.

Stieglitz went ahead with his plan to give “this woman” a show without divulging his intention to O’Keeffe. She found out about it by accident on a visit to New York and stalked into the gallery, demanding that the drawings be taken down. Stieglitz calmly ignored her expostulations and told her she had no right to withhold her work from the world. The force of his conviction may have made O’Keeffe feel like an ingrate, for she withdrew her objection.

In the months that followed, O’Keeffe, who had moved to Texas where she was giving art lessons, was constantly in Stieglitz’s thoughts. His letters to her were filled with passionate expressions of concern for her future as an artist, but his words grew increasingly amorous as his outpourings received a ready response. Letters passed between them at a furious rate, sometimes as many as five a day. “They knock me down,” O’Keeffe wrote to Anita Pollitzer, “but I get up again.”

Stieglitz was waiting to welcome O’Keeffe when she returned to New York in May 1917. The two wanted to marry, but there was one snag. Stieglitz already had a wife. The marriage was moribund, and Stieglitz intended to get a divorce. This did not save them from the censure of many family members and friends who disapproved of the relationship. Stieglitz’s wife came from a wealthy family, and he had used some of her money to subsidize his artistic ventures. These funds were cut off, and Stieglitz was reduced to accepting handouts from his brothers to survive. Camera Work ceased publication, and his gallery closed.

The lean years ended in 1921 with a triumphant exhibition of Stieglitz’s photographs; O’Keeffe had posed for forty-five of them, and they created a sensation. O’Keeffe became an instant celebrity, and Stieglitz was able to command the exorbitant sum of five thousand dollars for a single photograph of her. Two years later he arranged an exhibition of one hundred O’Keeffe paintings and drawings. Twenty sold immediately, and O’Keeffe’s career was launched. The next year, following his divorce, she and Stieglitz were married.

The marriage, which ended with Stieglitz’s death in 1946, was marked by long separations as O’Keeffe was drawn increasingly to the American Southwest, the inspiration for much of her art. Sun-bleached skulls in desert landscapes and oversized flowers in extreme close-up are the most common motifs in her paintings. She outlived her husband by more than forty years, and when she died, at ninety-eight, her paintings sold for millions of dollars. Today they hang in museums and private collections throughout the United States. Her reputation continues to grow, and today she is deemed by most critics the greater artist of the two.

content.question: Why is the meeting between Pollitzer and Stieglitz described as fateful?
content.answer: Because it marked the beginning of O’Keeffe’s rise to fame and changed the course of her career.

content.question: Why might Pollitzer have had reason to fear O’Keeffe’s censure?
content.answer: She had disregarded O'Keeffe's injunction to show the drawings to no one.

content.question: Why was O’Keeffe taken by surprise when she saw her works exhibited?
content.answer: Because Stieglitz had not divulged his plans to her.

content.question: Why do you think O’Keeffe expostulated with Stieglitz about the exhibition of her work?
content.answer: O'Keeffe deemed her paintings of little merit and wanted no one other than Pollitzer to see them.

content.question: Why is it unlikely that O’Keeffe was living in a very sumptuous style in Texas?
content.answer: Because she was a little-known art teacher giving lessons and not earning much.

content.question: How did Stieglitz’s voluble nature express itself while O’Keeffe was in Texas?
content.answer: He sent her frequent, passionate letters, sometimes five a day.

content.question: How did O’Keeffe respond to Stieglitz’s amorous letters?
Why might Stieglitz’s first wife have considered him an ingrate?
content.answer: He used money to subsidize his gallery and magazine and then left her.

content.question: Do you think five thousand dollars is an exorbitant price for a photograph? Explain.
Why did the breakup of Stieglitz’s marriage probably not come as a surprise?
Would you say that the motifs of O’Keeffe’s paintings are unusual? Why or why not?
Why would it be inaccurate to say that O’Keeffe’s paintings are belittled today?
content.answer: Because her paintings are celebrated and considered highly valuable today.
